title: 107_hr1526
content: The "Agriculture Competition Enhancement Act of 2001" prohibits the acquisition of voting securities or assets in the livestock, poultry, or agricultural commodity business if it exceeds $1,000,000,000 and reduces competition, affecting prices paid to producers. The "Agriculture Competition Enhancement Act of 2001" requires individuals purchasing livestock, poultry, or agricultural commodities for wholesale resale to file a notification with the Secretary. The Secretary must publish the notification in the Federal Register, accept public comments, and review the proposed acquisition within 30 days to assess its impact on producer prices. The "Agriculture Competition Enhancement Act of 2001" mandates individuals in the livestock, poultry, or agricultural commodities industry to notify the Secretary of any acquisitions involving key market players. The Secretary conducts a review to determine if the acquisition would lead to increased market power or potential anticompetitive behavior. A report with detailed findings and economic analysis is prepared and transmitted to the Office of Special Counsel for Agriculture and published in the Federal Register. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT PROVISIONS: Clayton Act sections apply to violations of section 2. SEC. 5. SPECIAL COUNSEL FOR AGRICULTURE: Office established for agricultural antitrust issues. SEC. 6. GAO STUDY. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the Grain Inspection, Packers and Stockyard Administration's need for additional resources to monitor the meat packing industry and disparities in administrative authority. A report on the findings and recommendations must be submitted to Congress within 1 year. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms used in the Act, such as "antitrust laws," "basic agricultural commodity," "livestock," "person," "poultry," and "Secretary."
